titleInfo.title: High Dimensional Classification for Skew-Normal Data

mods:mods.abstract: Skewed data are ubiquitous in various research fields, including environmental, financial, and biomedical areas. Skewed data greatly challenge the classical statistical analysis especially when we perform classification in high-dimensional settings. In my dissertation, we mainly study the high-dimensional classification under three proposed models. Such skewed data require approaches distinct from classical methods. Unfortunately, the methods fail to adequately capture data asymmetry in real data. In Chapter 2, we propose a high-dimensional classification model called the SKNC model (short for SKew-Normal Classification). By incorporating the skew-normal distribution in \cite{azzalini1985start}, the SKNC model naturally models skewness in classification. We further develop a novel classifier to estimate the SKNC model, in which robust estimators are employed to quantify the level of skewness. An efficient algorithm is proposed to implement the penalized estimation. Theoretical results rigorously show that SKNC achieves variable selection, penalized estimation, and prediction consistency, especially in high-dimensional settings. We empirically demonstrate the superior performance of SKNC over existing methods in simulated and real datasets. Under the independence of variables, SKNC is coherent with NSC (Nearest Shrunken Centroids method) which is a popular high-dimensional classifier. Therefore, we could show that SKNC is more competitive than NSC. Also, we simplify the model with independent variables, so we focus on the new challenge of skewness of data. However, introducing a multivariate case of the SKNC model is also needed, being potentially relevant for practical applications. For example, gene expressions are strongly correlated in microarrays. Initiated by the pioneering work of \cite{azzalini1985start}, the number of contributions in multivariate non-normal models has rapidly grown. In the following chapters, we focus on two different multivariate skew normal models. In Chapter 3, we propose a multivariate high-dimensional discriminant analysis model called the MSKNC model (short for Multivariate SKew-Normal Classification). By incorporating the multivariate skew-normal distribution proposed by \cite{azzalini1996multivariate}, the MSKNC model has a close connection with the LDA model, but it applies more generally. The MSKNC model provides more flexibility on skewed data than the LDA model. Theoretical results confirm that the proposed method achieves variable selection and prediction consistency, even in high-dimensional settings. The superior performance of MSKNC over existing methods is demonstrated in simulations and a real dataset. In Chapter 4, we propose a multivariate high-dimensional discriminant analysis model called the MSN model (short for Multivariate SKew-Normal model) with a block-diagonal covariance. By incorporating the multivariate skew-normal distribution proposed by the unrestricted model, \cite{bhingare2019semiparametric}, the MSN model can deal with skewness for classification. Unlike the MSKNC model, the MSN model preserves independent univariate skew-normal distributions for its marginals. We examine this method with simulations including various scenarios and further demonstrate it with a real-world dataset.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
High-dimensional classification, Linear discriminant analysis, Multi-class sparse discriminant analysis, Robust estimator, Skew-normal data, Skewness
Qing Mai, Professor Directing Dissertation; Qian Zhang, University Representative; Debajyoti Sinha, Committee Member; Fred Huï¬€er, Committee Member.
